name: Senmaizuke (Japanese Pickled Turnip)
description: Marinated in a sweet pickling solution with kombu and red chili, Senmaizuke (literally “thousand-sliced pickles“) is a popular Kyoto-style pickled turnip. Serve them as an accompaniment to any Japanese meal and enjoy between dishes as a palate cleanser.
recipeIngredient: 1 lb Japanese turnips (kabu) ((I use regular turnips))
5 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt ((3% of the turnip weight; 13.5 g))
1 piece kombu (dried kelp) ((10 g; 4 x 4 inches or 10 x 10 cm per piece))

recipeInstructions.name: To Make the Sweet Pickling Solution

itemListElement.text: In a small saucepan, combine 1 cup rice vinegar (unseasoned), ¾ cup sugar, and 1 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt.
itemListElement.name: In a small saucepan, combine 1 cup rice vinegar (unseasoned), ¾ cup sugar, and 1 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt.

itemListElement.text: Bring the liquid to a gentle simmer over medium heat. While mixing the liquid, let it simmer for a minute until the sugar dissolves and the vinegar smell is removed. Turn off the heat and set it aside to cool.
itemListElement.name: Bring the liquid to a gentle simmer over medium heat. While mixing the liquid, let it simmer for a minute until the sugar dissolves and the vinegar smell is removed. Turn off the heat and set it aside to cool.

itemListElement.text: Peel 1 lb Japanese turnips (kabu) using a vegetable peeler or a knife.
itemListElement.name: Peel 1 lb Japanese turnips (kabu) using a vegetable peeler or a knife.

itemListElement.text: Cut the turnips into 1⁄16-inch (2-mm) slices. Here, I use a mandoline slicer to achieve a uniform thickness.
itemListElement.name: Cut the turnips into 1⁄16-inch (2-mm) slices. Here, I use a mandoline slicer to achieve a uniform thickness.

itemListElement.text: Sprinkle 5 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt all over the turnip slices and rub/knead/massage the turnip well with salt. Set aside for 30 minutes. The turnip slices will start to sweat and release moisture; this helps remove bitterness, too.
itemListElement.name: Sprinkle 5 tsp Diamond Crystal kosher salt all over the turnip slices and rub/knead/massage the turnip well with salt. Set aside for 30 minutes. The turnip slices will start to sweat and release moisture; this helps remove bitterness, too.

itemListElement.text: After 30 minutes, transfer to a sieve and rinse the turnip slices under running water to get rid of the salt and sliminess.
itemListElement.name: After 30 minutes, transfer to a sieve and rinse the turnip slices under running water to get rid of the salt and sliminess.

itemListElement.text: Squeeze the turnip slices to remove excess water and stack the slices.
itemListElement.name: Squeeze the turnip slices to remove excess water and stack the slices.

itemListElement.text: Cut 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) into smaller pieces (because I use three different size jars). Remove and discard the seeds from 1 dried red chili pepper and slice into rounds.
itemListElement.name: Cut 1 piece kombu (dried kelp) into smaller pieces (because I use three different size jars). Remove and discard the seeds from 1 dried red chili pepper and slice into rounds.

itemListElement.text: Prepare clean jars or airtight containers.
itemListElement.name: Prepare clean jars or airtight containers.

itemListElement.text: Put some turnip slices, a piece of kombu, and red chili in each jar, and pour the sweet pickling solution over to cover the turnip.
itemListElement.name: Put some turnip slices, a piece of kombu, and red chili in each jar, and pour the sweet pickling solution over to cover the turnip.

itemListElement.text: Place the pickling weight (or utensil) on top of the turnip and put the lid on. Keep the jars in the refrigerator overnight.
itemListElement.name: Place the pickling weight (or utensil) on top of the turnip and put the lid on. Keep the jars in the refrigerator overnight.

itemListElement.text: The pickled turnips are now ready to serve. You can remove the pickling weight. Kombu gets slimy after soaking in the liquid overnight, making the pickling solution slightly slimy/thick. However, this is a feature of Senmaizuke and you do not need to worry about it.
itemListElement.name: The pickled turnips are now ready to serve. You can remove the pickling weight. Kombu gets slimy after soaking in the liquid overnight, making the pickling solution slightly slimy/thick. However, this is a feature of Senmaizuke and you do not need to worry about it.

itemListElement.text: Transfer the turnip slices onto a plate. I like serving each slice of turnip folded as you see in the picture. Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Transfer the turnip slices onto a plate. I like serving each slice of turnip folded as you see in the picture. Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the pickles in the marinade for up to 4 days in the refrigerator. Use clean utensils to pick up the turnip to serve from the jar.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the pickles in the marinade for up to 4 days in the refrigerator. Use clean utensils to pick up the turnip to serve from the jar.

review.reviewBody: Really delicious! Nice pickled flavor with the texture of  gari. I  didn't find these to be slimy (just the piece of kombu itself, and not the turnip). Not really spicy either so  if someone wants that they  should add even more peppers. Thanks for sharing.

This looks like a wonderful recipe. I'll have to try and grow Shogoin Kabu! There was a website called "Kanako's Kitchen" which had a very similar recipe. From what I can tell, they're essentially identical.

I am already a happy subscriber to JOC and wish to thank you for the excellent education you are providing.  I live on Vancouver Island and our Mayor Maja recommended your site to me for which I am grateful.
